content.title: Circumference and Area
content.body:
For a circle with radius \(r\):
1. **Circumference:** \(2\pi r\)
2. **Area:** \(\pi r^2\)

**Note:** If the diameter \(d\) is given, remember \(r = d/2\). Take \(\pi = 22/7\) unless specified as \(3.14\).
content.analogy: Circumference is the length of the fence around a circular park. Area is the amount of grass needed to cover the park.

content.title: Area of a Sector
content.body:
A sector is a portion of a circle enclosed by two radii and an arc.

- **Area of Sector:** \(\frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times \pi r^2\)
- **Length of an Arc:** \(\frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times 2\pi r\)
Where \(\theta\) is the angle of the sector.
content.analogy: A sector is like a slice of pizza!

content.title: Area of a Segment
content.body:
A segment is a portion of a circle enclosed by a chord and an arc.

**Area of Minor Segment:**
\(\text{Area of Sector} - \text{Area of corresponding Triangle}\)

\[ \text{Area} = \left( \frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times \pi r^2 \right) - \left( \frac{1}{2}r^2 \sin \theta \right) \]

content.instruction: If the question asks for the 'Major' area, use this shortcut:
content.exactPhrase: Area of Major Sector = \(\text{Total Area of Circle} - \text{Area of Minor Sector}\). Alternatively, use the angle \((360^\circ - \theta)\) in the sector formula.

content.instruction: These appear often in 3-mark questions. Calculate the angle first:
content.exactPhrase: The minute hand of a clock describes \(360^\circ\) in 60 minutes. Therefore, in 1 minute, it rotates through \(6^\circ\). Angle \(\theta = (\text{minutes}) \times 6^\circ\).

content.question: Find the area of a sector of a circle with radius 6 cm if the angle of the sector is \(60^\circ\).
content.explanation: Area = \((60/360) \times (22/7) \times 6 \times 6\). This simplifies to \((1/6) \times (22/7) \times 36\), which is \(22/7 \times 6 = 132/7 \text{ cm}^2\).

content.hook: Length is Line, Area is Space
content.explanation: Arc length uses the circumference formula (\(2\pi r\)) because it's a line. Sector area uses the area formula (\(\pi r^2\)) because it's a 2D space.
